src package¶

Submodules¶

src.force module¶

implementation of the force-term

src.force.F(tp, source_time, Fx)[source]¶

dfnalskdnjflakjsdf lkjc fasdlkj

src.force.element_force_mat(f, J, W)[source]¶

Computes the Force Vector for each element

Parameters:
  • f – [ngll_el] numpy array
  • J – flattened Jacobian determinant vector [ngll_el] numpy corresponding to nodes numbers
  • W – weight vector [ngll_el] numpy corresponding to nodes numbers
Return type:

numpy [ngll_total]

The description of the Jacobian can be found on the theory documentation.

src.force.genforce(force_term, force_location, gll_coordinates)[source]¶
force(source_time_function,force_term,
force_location,gll_coordinates):

This function implements the force term of a point source for the seismic wave equation.

Parameters:
  • force_term – 2 element numpy array with forces in 2D
  • force_loc – 2 element numpy numpy array with force location
  • gll_coordinates –
src.force.global_force_vector(gll_coordinates, gll_connect, f, dN_local, W)[source]¶

Computes the Global Force Vector

Parameters:
  • gll_coordinates – numpy array of size [ngll_total]x[2] containing the coordinates of all the gll points
  • gll_connect – numpy array of size [el_no]x[ngll_el]. Contains the global indexing of gll nodes.
  • f – force vector [ngll_el] numpy
  • dN_local – Local derivative of shape functions at each gll point in an element. numpy` array of size [total ngll]x[2]x[total ngll]
  • W – Weight matrix [ngll_el] numpy corresponding to nodes numbers
Return type:

numpy [ngll_total]x[ngll_total] array

src.gll_library module¶

This is a function library for GLL interpolation and quadrature

Author: Lucas Sawade

src.gll_library.Jacobian(dN, x)[source]¶
src.gll_library.Jacobian(dN, x)[source]

Computes the Jacobian Matrix [dx/dxi] between the global and the local element coordinates

Parameters:
  • dN – shape function derivative matrix (numpy) [dim]x[Number of GLL points]
  • x – global node coordinates [dim]x[Number of GLL points] (numpy)
Return type:

numpy [dim]x[dim] array

The description of the Jacobian can be found on the theory documentation.

src.gll_library.Jacobian2D(dN, x)[source]¶
src.gll_library.Jacobian2D(dN, x)[source]

Computes the Jacobian Matrix [dx/dxi] between the global and the local element coordinates

Parameters:
  • dN – shape function derivative matrix (numpy) [dim]x[total Number of GLL points]
  • x – global node coordinates [dim]x[total Number of GLL points] (numpy)
Return type:

numpy [dim]x[dim] array

The description of the Jacobian can be found on the theory documentation.

src.gll_library.dN_local_2D(xi, eta)[source]¶
src.gll_library.dN_local(xi, eta)¶

Computes the flattened Jacobian for each GLL point. Numbering as described in the documentation.

Parameters:
  • xi – numpy 1D array of collocation points in xi direction
  • eta – numpy 1D array of collocation points in eta direction
Return type:

numpy array of size [total ngll]x[2]x[total ngll]

Needs to be computed once the beginning since it is the same for all elements. It’s the derivative of each shape function in each dimension computed at each gll point of the element.

src.gll_library.flattened_weights2D(w_xi, w_eta)[source]¶

..function:: flattened_Weights(xi,eta)

This function flattens the weights into a 1D array.

Parameters:
  • xi – numpy 1D array of weights corresponding to collocation points in xi direction
  • eta – numpy 1D array of weights corresponding to collocation points in eta direction
Return type:

numpy array of size 1x[len(xi)*len(eta)]

Numbering of the weights follows the numbering scheme in the documentation.

src.gll_library.gll_pw(N)[source]¶
src.gll_library.gll_pw(N)[source]
Parameters:N – Polynomial degree
Return type:1x2 tuple of 1D numpy 1x(N+1) arrays, the first containing the collocation points and the second containing quadrature weights

Takes in polynomial degree and returns the (N+1) points and weights Returns GLL (Gauss Lobato Legendre module with collocation points and weights)

src.gll_library.global_derivative(jacob, dNdxi)[source]¶
src.gll_library.global_derivative(jacob, dN)[source]

This function computes the global derivatives from the local shape function derivates.

Parameters:
  • jacob – the [dim]x[dim] numpy array containing the Jacobian transformation matrix.
  • dNdxi – local shapefunction derivative numpy array of size [dim]x[total Number of GLL points]
Return type:

global shapefunction derivative numpy array of size [dim]x[total Number of GLL points].

The global derivative is needed for the GLL quadrature on element level.

The algorithm is simple since

\[\frac{d}{dx} = J^{-1} \frac{d}{d\xi}\]
src.gll_library.lagrange(i, x, xi)[source]¶
src.gll_library.lagrange(i, x, xi)[source]

The algorithm follows the definition of the Lagrange Polynomial strictly.

Parameters:
  • i – Polynomial number.
  • x – location of evaluation.
  • xi – numpy 1D array of collocation points.
Return type:

value of Lagrange polynomial of order N (len(xi)-1) and polynomial number i [0, N-1] at location x at given collocation points xi (not necessarily the GLL-points)
src.gll_library.lagrange1st(i, x, xi)[source]¶
src.gll_library.lagrange1st(i, x, xi)[source]

Computes the 1st derivative of the lagrange polynomial in 1D.

Parameters:
  • i – polynomial number
  • x – location of evalutation
  • xi – collocation points
Return type:

return the value of the derivative of the lagrange polynomial in 1D at point x, of polynomial number i, with collocation points xi.

The derivative of the Lagrange polynomial is the Lagrange polynomial multiplied with the Legendre Polynomial. Through simplification which is described in detail in the documentation we can omit one numerator when k equals j.

src.gll_library.lagrange1st2D(i, x, xi, j, y, eta, d)[source]¶
src.gll_library.lagrange1st2D(x, xi, y, eta, d)[source]

Computes the 1st derivative of the 2D Lagrange polynomial.

Parameters:
  • i – polynomial number in 0-th dimension
  • x – location of evalutation in 0-th dimension
  • xi – collocation points in 0-th dimension
  • j – polynomial number in 1st dimension
  • y – location of evalutation in 1st dimension
  • eta – collocation points in 1st dimension
  • d – dimension of differentiation (0 or 2)
Return type:

return the value of the derivative of the lagrange polynomial in 1D at point x, of polynomial number i, with collocation points xi.

This function computes the 2D derivative of the lagrange polynomial in dimension d (0 or 1). The collocation points in the first and second dimension are xi and eta, respectively. The location is (x,y) and the numbers of the polynomials in the different dimensions are i and j.

src.gll_library.lagrange2D(i, x, xi, j, y, eta)[source]¶
src.gll_library.lagrange2D(i, x, xi, j, y, eta)[source]

Computes the lagrange polynomial in two dimensions :param i: polynomial number 0-th dimension :param x: location of evalutation 0-th dimension :param xi: collocation points 0-th dimension

Parameters:
  • j – polynomial number in 1st dimension
  • y – location of evalutation in 1st dimension
  • eta – collocation points in 1st dimension
Return type:

returns value of Lagrange polynomial of order N (len(xi)-1) and polynomial number i [0, N-1] at location x at given collocation points xi (not necessarily the GLL-points) calculates the 2D lagrange polynomial given collocation point sets xi and eta the coordinate x,y, and the polynomial numbers i,j
src.gll_library.lagrangeDerMat2D(x, xi, y, eta)[source]¶
src.gll_library.lagrangeDerMat2D(x, xi, y, eta)[source]

This function computes the 2D dervative matrix of the lagrange polynomial in the form

 _         _     _                                          _
|  dN/dxi   |   |  dN1/dxi  dN2/dxi  dN3/dxi  ...  dNn/dxi   |
|           | = |                                            |
|_ dN/deta _|   |_ dN1/deta dN2/deta dN3/deta ...  dNn/deta _|
Parameters:
  • x – location in 0th dimension
  • xi – numpy 1D array of collocation points in 0th dimension
  • y – location in 1st dimension
  • eta – numpy 1D array collocation points in 1st dimension
Return type:

numpy 2x[len(xi)*len(eta)] array

For the numbering of the shape functions see documentation.

src.gll_library.legendre(i, x, xi)[source]¶
src.gll_library.legendre(i, x, xi)[source]

Computes the legendre polynomial.

Parameters:
  • i – number of polynomial
  • x – location of evalutation
  • xi – numpy 1D array of collocation points.
Return type:

returns the value of Legendre Polynomial P_i(x) at location x given collocation points xi (not necessarily GLL points) and polynomial number i.

Extremely simple algorithm.

src.loc2glob module¶

src.loc2glob.local2global(Me, Mg, gll_connect, el_no)[source]¶
src.loc2glob.local2global(Me, Mg, gll_connect, el_no)[source]

Takes in an element matrix and global matrix as input and returns the modified global matrix.

Parameters:
  • Me – Element numpy matrix of shape [ngll_el]x[ngll_el].
  • Mg – Global numpy matrix of shape [ngll_total]x[ngll_total].
  • gll_connect – Containing the GLL connectivities and used for array conversion. numpy matrix of shape [ngll_total]x[ngll_el]
  • el_no – Index of the element whose Me is being sent to add into Mg. Single element``numpy`` array.
Return type:

numpy [ngll_total]x[ngll_total] array

Computes the simplest Element Mass Matrix M_e for each element

Parameters:
  • rho – flattened density matrix [1]x[total Number of GLL points] (numpy)
  • J – flattened Jacobian determinant matrix [1]x[total Number of GLL points] (numpy)
  • W – flattened weight matrix [1]x[total Number of GLL points] (numpy)
Return type:

numpy [ngll_total]x[ngll_total] array

The description of the Jacobian can be found on the theory documentation.

Parameters:

  • gll_connect – numpy array of size [el_no]x[ngll_el]. Contains the global indexing of gll nodes.

  • dN_local – Local derivative of shape functions at each gll point in an element. numpy` array of size [total ngll]x[2]x[total ngll]

Return type:

numpy [ngll_total]x[ngll_total] array

src.mesh_plot module¶

This is script contains functions to plot a mesh

src.mesh_plot.plot_elements(X, Y, connect, gll_coordinates, gll_connect, num_o_el='all', plot_el_num='no', plot_node_num='no', plot_axis='yes')[source]¶

This function plots the GLL points as well as control points in 2D

Parameters:
  • X – 1xN vectors with node coordinates
  • Y – 1xN vectors with node coordinates
  • connect – connectivity matrix depending on the number of GLL points, ([total number of elements] X [GLL^2])
  • num_o_el – number of elements to be plotted, default is string valued ‘all’, set to number small
  • plot_el_num – default is “no”, change to “yes” if element numbers should be plotted
  • plot_node_num – default is “no”, change to “yes” if node numbers should be plotted
  • plot_axis – default is “yes”, if you want to omit axes set to “no”
Return type:

A figure plotting the ‘num_o_el’ 2D elements
src.mesh_plot.test_interp()[source]¶

Running the example and plots them subsequently.

src.mesh_spec module¶

This is script contains functions used to get from a quadrilateral mesh to a Spectral-Element mesh. File for mesh object creation?

src.mesh_spec.assignSeismicProperties(velocity_model, gll_coordinates)[source]¶

Reads an .npy file that contains a numpy array with velocity model of the format.

Columns: X, Y, Z, rho, vp ,vs

Then, it assigns the properties to the interpolated mesh using the nearest neighbour principle.

Parameters:
  • v_name – velocity model array specified as above.
  • gll_coordinates – coordinate matrix of the interpolated GLL points using the original matrix.
Return type:

Nx3 numpy array with the seismic properties for each node in gll_coordinates

 
Columns: rho, vp, vs

I think this should be correct.

src.mesh_spec.mesh_interp2D(X, Y, Z, connect, ngllx, nglly)[source]¶

Creates new gll point mesh from initial control point mesh for variable accuracy vs. efficiency.

Parameters:
  • X – x coordinates in Nx1 numpy array
  • Y – y coordinates in Nx1 numpy array
  • Z – z coordinates in Nx1 numpy array
  • connect – 1x[Number of control points] numpy array that defines the connectivity of each element
  • ngllx – number of new gll points in xi direction
  • nglly – number of new gll points in eta direction

Function takes in coordinates of meshgrid and its connectivity matrix. Then, it interpolates the GLL points onto the global grid and defines the numbering for the new found set of points.

src.mesh_spec.readEx(name)[source]¶

Function reads Exodus file and outputs Coordinates, connection matrix, boundary coordinates and nodes.

src.mesh_spec.readUniformVelocity(input_mesh, outfilename)[source]¶

This function takes in an input mesh and assigns velocity to the depths defined in the script below.

Saves .npy array file with

Columns: X, Y, Z, rho, vp, vs

src.model_parameters module¶

Function set to define Model parameters

src.model_parameters.velocity_conversion(rho, vp, vs)[source]¶
src.model_parameters.velocity_conversion(rho, vp, vs)[source]

Converts the density, vp and vs velocity to the Lame parameters

Parameters:
  • rho – 1D numpy array containing density values
  • vp – 1D numpy array containing density values
  • vs – 1D numpy array containing density values
Return type:

2 element tupel() containing mu and lambda numpy arrays of same size as the parameters.

Mathematical solution .. math:

\begin{align}
    \mu &= \rho \cdot V s ^ { 2 }\\
    \lambda &= ( V p ) ^ { 2 } \cdot \rho - 2 \mu
\end{align}

src.plot.main()[source]¶

src.stiffness_matrix module¶

src.stiffness_matrix.element_stiffness_matrix(gll_coords_el, dim, ngll_el, dN_local, comp, W, lmd, mu)[source]¶

Computes the Elemetal Stiffness Matrix in three parts A,B,C for each element.

Parameters:
  • gll_coords – the global coordinates for the gll points in a particular element.
  • dim – the dimensionaloty of our system. Currently 2D. So dim=2.
  • dN_local – Local derivative of shape functions at each gll point in an element. numpy` array of size [total ngll]x[2]x[total ngll]
  • comp – the component of u that we are solving for when calling this function
  • W – flattened weight matrix [1]x[total Number of GLL points] (numpy)
  • lmd – the flattened $lambda$ array [1]x[total Number of GLL points] (numpy)
  • mu – the flattened $mu$ array [1]x[total Number of GLL points] (numpy)
Return type:

A and B are numpy [dim]x[ngll_el]x[ngll_el] array and C is numpy [ngll_el]x[ngll_el] array

The description of the Jacobian can be found on the theory documentation.

src.stiffness_matrix.global_stiffness_matrix(gll_coordinates, gll_connect, dN_local, W, comp, dim, lmd, mu)[source]¶

Computes the Global Mass Matrix Mg

Parameters:
  • gll_coordinates – numpy array of size [ngll_total]x[dim] containing the coordinates of all the gll points
  • gll_connect – numpy array of size [el_no]x[ngll_el]. Contains the global indexing of gll nodes.
  • dN_local – Local derivative of shape functions at each gll point in an element. numpy` array of size [total ngll]x[2]x[total ngll]
  • W – flattened weight matrix [1]x[ngll_el] (numpy)
  • comp – depends on which component of u we are solving for
  • dim – the dimensionality of our system. For now its 2.
  • lmd – the flattened $lambda$ array [1]x[total Number of GLL points] (numpy)
  • mu – the flattened $mu$ array [1]x[total Number of GLL points] (numpy)
Return type:

Ag and Bg are numpy [dim]x[ngll_total]x[ngll_total] array and C is numpy [ngll_total]x[ngll_total] array
